title: How to Decorate a Bachelor Pad

steps.headline: Choose seating that has a similar color palette to make it look uniform.
steps.description: If you want a classic bachelor pad aesthetic, opt for chairs and couches made with either black or brown leather. Otherwise, pick fabrics that have neutral tones, such as beige, grey, or brown, to help keep your place feel open and relaxing. Make sure you get furniture that fits well in your space and looks aesthetically pleasing so your bachelor pad doesn’t feel too cramped. Try to keep at least 1 couch and 1–2 chairs in the main living area of your bachelor pad so you have room for multiple guests. Look for matching furniture sets if you’re able to so your room feels more cohesive. Check local online markets, like Craigslist or Facebook Marketplace, to look for furniture if you’re on a budget. Many people post and sell their older furniture when they buy something new. Avoid using outdoor furniture or seating that has bright and annoying patterns since it could make your place seem less refined.Tip: Bachelor pads tend to have a minimalistic feel, so avoid getting ornate pieces of furniture. Instead, get items that have long straight lines and single colors.

steps.headline: Place coffee and side tables near seating so you have places to keep drinks.
steps.description: Use a neutral color, such as black, white, or brown, for your tables and try to find matching styles. If you want a modern look, opt for square or rectangular tables made from wood, glass, or metal. For something with a classic feel, search for rounded wooden tables. Make sure the tables are within reach of your furniture so you’re able to use them when you need to. Side tables also make great places to put lamps and other small decorations to make your bachelor pad feel homier. Some coffee tables also have hidden storage options where you can keep blankets, movies, or games so they’re out of sight.

steps.headline: Get a nice TV and sound system so you’re able to entertain.
steps.description: Look for a TV that’s large enough to fit in your space so you’re able to see it clearly from any seat. Keep the TV against the wall on an entertainment center so it’s at eye level so you don’t have to crane your neck to see it. Plug an external sound system into the TV so you can get the best audio from it. If there are surround sound speakers, set them on an entertainment center, attach them to speaker stands, or mount them on the wall. Speakers are also great for playing music while you’re entertaining or lounging around. Many times, you can find speakers that you can connect to your phone using Bluetooth. It’s okay if you don’t have speakers for your TV.Variation: Mount your TV on the wall if you’re able to if you don’t have room for an entertainment center.

steps.headline: Find a dining table so you have a comfortable place to eat.
steps.description: Try to find a dining table and set of chairs that match the aesthetic and design of the rest of your room. Choose a table that has enough room for you and at least 1 other person so you can entertain and feed guests whenever you have someone over. Place the dining table near your kitchen or living room area. Opt for an extendable dining table that has a leaf insert if you want the option to make your table longer to entertain more guests. You can find many tables and chairs in dining sets to ensure they have a matching style.

steps.headline: Use a sturdy bed frame for your mattress to raise it off the ground.
steps.description: Avoid leaving your mattress on the floor since it can make your bedroom look messy or cluttered. Search for a slotted frame that matches the rest of your room so you don’t need to buy a separate box spring mattress. Set up the frame so one of the short sides is against the wall so you can comfortably get into bed from either long side of the mattress. Search for a frame that has a headboard if you want to add a decorative touch to your bedroom. It’s okay to put the long side of the mattress and frame against the wall if you need to save space. Put a bed skirt on the frame before setting your mattress on top of it if you want to hide the space underneath it.

steps.headline: Look for shelves or hidden storage to organize your space easier.
steps.description: If you have the floor space, opt for large bookcases, drawers, or shelving units for you to keep your things. Do your best to organize everything in your storage shelves so they have a clean appearance and so you’re easily able to reach the things you use most frequently. You can use them for storing books, knick-knacks, or board games. Look for organization cubes if you don’t want the items on your shelf visible. Get drawers or storage containers that easily fit in a closet so they don’t take up as much floor space. You may also try to get decorative shelves that function as an art piece as well as storage.

steps.headline: Look for a desk and comfortable chair if you want to do work from home.
steps.description: Get a desk that has a simple aesthetic or design that’s similar to the other furniture in your home, and set it up near an outlet so you’re able to plug in a computer. Pick an office chair that’s comfortable to sit in for long periods of time and keep it at your desk. Try finding a desk that has drawers or storage space so your work surface doesn’t get too cluttered with items. Avoid working at your dining table since you’ll need to clear it off if you ever want to sit down and eat with guests. You may also use your desk chair as additional seating if you need it.

steps.headline: Try a bar unit to keep any liquor or drinkware.
steps.description: If you want to move the bar unit around to better entertain guests, opt for a cart that has wheels so you’re able to roll it around your place. Otherwise, try to find a sturdy bar cabinet and keep it between your kitchen and living space. Store any liquor bottles or drinkware on the cart so you can easily grab something to drink when you want it. You do not need to get a bar unit if you don’t want one, but it can help free up counter or cabinet space.

steps.headline: Distribute your furniture throughout your home so each room has balance.
steps.description: Avoid putting all of your furniture in a single room since it can make the space feel cluttered and the rest of your home look empty. Try to spread your furniture and decor throughout your home so you have space to feel comfortable. Make sure there’s enough space for you to walk around your home without having to squeeze past any of your items. Keep enough seating in rooms where you plan on entertaining for you and your guests. For example, rather than keeping a ping pong table in your living room, you may instead keep it in a spare bedroom to make it a game room.Variation: If you don’t have extra space for your things, consider selling or donating some of your items to downsize what you have. Only keep what you use the most frequently.

steps.headline: Paint your walls to instantly change the look of your space.
steps.description: If you want your space to look more open, opt for lighter colors, such as grey, beige, or light blue. Make sure the colors you use complements the colors of your furniture, or else they may clash. Try to make 1–2 walls in each room a darker complementary color to add more visual interest to the space. Avoid using dark colors for every wall since it could make your place feel more enclosed. Don’t use colors that are too bright since they could get overwhelming to look at. Try painting over bricks or other natural wall surfaces to give them a striking appearance. Otherwise, you can leave them exposed for a rustic look. If you have the time and budget, try painting your ceilings 1–2 shades lighter than the walls to give the illusion that they’re taller.Warning: If you don’t own your property, make sure to check with your landlord before painting the walls to see if you’re allowed to.

steps.headline: Look for movie posters or art prints to hang around a living area.
steps.description: Try to look for posters or art prints that have similar or complementary color schemes so they don’t clash with one another. Opt for posters that are the same size to make the room feel balanced. Keep the posters in matching frames to help them look more cohesive and to protect them from damage. Many times, you can find posters and frames in big box stores. Search online for art prints since many will have them in standard poster sizes. Try hanging the posters in a straight line across the wall to give your room a gallery-like feel. Bachelor pads are known for looking more refined, so avoid hanging posters that have lewd or graphic imagery since it will take away the ambiance. If you're an artistic or creative person, you could also consider making your own art prints.

steps.headline: Hang personal photos if you want to make your place seem more lived in.
steps.description: Try to get matching frames for each of your photo prints so they have a cohesive look when you put them on your walls. Start by arranging the photos how you want them on your floor and take pictures of their spacing and layouts so you can remember them. You can try using a grid pattern, or setting a larger photo in the middle of smaller ones. If you want to make a more freeform design, try making a collage of unframed photos and attaching them to your wall with poster putty. If you don’t have room to hang framed photos, you can also put them on table surfaces as added decoration.

steps.headline: Opt for paintings on canvas if you want the art to pop from the wall.
steps.description: Look for a piece of art that has an accent color or has a similar palette as the rest of the decor in your home. Make sure the center of the artwork hangs at eye level so people can easily look at it when they come over. If you’re placing art over furniture, keep the bottom of the piece about 6–8 inches (15–20 cm) above the top of the feature. Use art that’s about ⅔ the length of furniture if you’re hanging it over a piece, or about 4/7 of the length of an empty wall. If you want to make a gallery wall with multiple pieces of art, leave about 3–6 inches (7.6–15.2 cm) between them. You don’t need to hang art, but it can make your space feel more lived in. If you want to hang multiple art pieces, try to keep about 3–6 inches (7.6–15.2 cm) between each one. Avoid paintings that look gaudy or overly showy since they can make your bachelor pad seem less sophisticated.

steps.headline: Use floating shelves if you want additional storage.
steps.description: Opt for floating shelves that are the same colors as the other pieces of furniture in your room. Make sure the shelves are at a height where you can easily reach them so you’re able to grab your items or change the decorations you’re displaying on them. Keep decorations or items that make sense to store in the space, such as books and candles in a living room, or dinnerware and glasses in a kitchen. Make sure the shelves don’t extend out so far that someone may bump into them easily. Try to keep the items on your shelves to a similar color scheme so it doesn’t look too cluttered. Try stacking items on your shelves to add vertical design to them.

steps.headline: Use blankets and throw pillows to make seating more comfortable.
steps.description: Try to keep 1–2 throw pillows on chairs, couches, or beds since they can add a decorative touch that makes your space seem more inviting. Choose solid colors or patterns that add an accent to your room. Drape blankets over the backs of your furniture, or fold them neatly in a basket nearby so they’re easy to access. For example, if you have light brown furniture and a piece of art that has some red in it, you may opt for red throw pillows and a dark brown blanket.

steps.headline: Add accents to your rooms with light fixtures.
steps.description: Try to get lamps that have soft white light and a clean, simple appearance so they make your rooms feel warmer and create a better ambiance. If you have table space, opt for short table lamps. If you need to fill a corner in your room or create an accent piece, look for a floor lamp that has a single bulb on top. Look for something that has a different color or finish, such as stainless steel, so they stand out more. Try to keep the light fixtures similar in appearance between each room so they don’t clash with one another.

steps.headline: Hang curtains in front of your windows for added decoration and privacy.
steps.description: Measure the widths of your windows and get curtain rods for each of them. You may choose extendable rods that fit inside the window well or set length bars that attach to the outside. Choose solid-colored or patterned drapes that are long enough to reach past the bottom of the windows. Keep the curtains closed whenever you want more privacy or when it’s too bright outside. Thick curtains can also help insulate your home during cold weather if you keep them closed. Avoid using towels or bed sheets as makeshift curtains since they won’t look as nice on your wall.

steps.headline: Lay rugs on the floor to create more visual interest in your room.
steps.description: You may choose patterned rugs or ones that have solid colors depending on your preference. If you’re able to, get a rug that’s large enough so it extends out by about 1–2 feet (30–61 cm) past the edges of your furniture. Otherwise, opt for smaller rugs that you can fit underneath a table or accent piece. Rugs look great underneath large pieces of furniture or right inside your entryway. You may also get bath mats for your bathroom so you’re able to dry off your feet when you get out of the shower. Don’t use regular rugs since they may not be able to handle water as well.

steps.headline: Keep live plants throughout your home to give it a fresh touch.
steps.description: Opt for low-maintenance plants, such as succulents, ficus, pothos, and rubber plants so you don’t have to worry about them as much as more demanding species. Keep the plants in decorative pots or planters and use them as centerpieces on tables or as window dressing. Make sure to water the plants when the growing medium feels dry so they continue to grow and stay healthy. Try growing rabbit’s ear, spider plant, peace lilies, and bamboo for more low-maintenance plants. You may also try growing herbs or vegetables in your kitchen window so you have fresh plants to use while you’re cooking. Avoid buying plants that require constant trimming or pruning since they require a lot of upkeep.

steps.headline: Get game tables or board games if you plan on entertaining others.
steps.description: If you have the space, try to find a ping pong or pool table that you can keep in your space so you can play with your guests. If you don’t have the room or budget for a large game table, try buying board games that you can keep on a shelf or in a closet so you have more options for fun things to do at home. Try using a dartboard if you want a game that doesn’t take a lot of space. Make sure the darts don’t damage the wall where you hang it.
